page.title: 13ATTRACTIONS OF HAMSTERLEY
page.content: On the way to the Church,which stands 1/2 mile east of the village can be seen an excellent example of the medieval open field system with its long narrow strips-STETHS-separated from each other by BALKS-portions of the wall which can also be seen.On the north side of Bedburn is The Castles,a fortified enclosure of stone walls at the foot of a ridge of hills.It has puzzled antiquarians but is believed to have been a camp of protection built on Roman plan.The ruins of Bedburn Mill remind us of the industry once in the area.A rectangular site of a moated homestead may be seen at East Shipley.Near Park House is a sulphur spring,samples having lately been taken for analyses for radio active properties.Hoppyland Hall,now in ruins was once the seat of the local squire The stone is now used to repair walls.
